channel.title: Maths coursework proving it
channel.description:
right so i have this year 10 coursework that i have to complete early because im going on holiday i have to find the t total using the t number.
so i have a 9 by 9 grid, 1-81 and here is an example of a t
|13 14 15| |23| |32| so the t number is 32 and the t total (all of the numbers is added together) is 97 so i have found that the forumula for this is 5N-63 (n being t total) but my teacher says that i have to prove that this formula works using algebra but i dont understand how to prove it using algebra
thanks -Saml
[br][size=1]Posted at: June 18, 2006, 03:48:03 pm[/size][hr]nvm i got it now :) i just had to say
|n-19,n-18,n-17| |n-9| |n | so n-19+n-18+n-17+n-9+n= 5n-63 :)
but now i have to find the formula for any grid :S
i know that i will have to use the size of the grid in the formula but i dont know how[br][size=1]Posted at: June 19, 2006, 02:29:25 pm[/size][hr]rofl ive got that now, im just finding it hard to explain it/ prove it

item.title: Maths coursework proving it
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

im also in year 10, im doing that same coursework, the forumla for any grid is Ttotal=5N-7G

look with 9x9 grids, tnumber=20

(20x5)-(7x9)= 100-63 = 37

this is how you prove this
( ) means a box with a number in it

t=tnumber
g=gridsize

(t-2g-1)(t-2g)(t-2g+1)
(t-g)
(t)

this is

t+t-g+t-2g+t-2g-1+t-2g+1 therefore…

t+t+t+t+t-g+2g+2g+2g+1-1 therefore…

5t-7g ta-da you’ve proved your rule

now do some testing and you should get around 6,6,6. to get anymore, you have to have vectors, which are really hard
